citation.article-title: Spirosoma spitsbergense sp. nov. and Spirosoma luteum sp. nov., isolated from a high Arctic permafrost soil, and emended description of the genus Spirosoma.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Spirosoma spitsbergense sp. nov.
Spirosoma spitsbergense (spits.berg.en′se. N.L. neut. adj. spitsbergense pertaining to Spitsbergen in the high Arctic, northern Norway, from where the type strain was isolated).
Cells are Gram-negative rods, 1 μm in diameter and 4–10 μm in length, non-motile, non-spore-forming and devoid of gas vacuoles.
A diffusible yellow pigment that does not belong to the flexirubin type is produced.
When grown in R2A broth, cells form long filaments up to 80 μm long.
Colonies on R2A agar are circular with a diameter of 0.5–1.5 mm after 2 weeks incubation at 25 °C.
Growth occurs aerobically at 4–30 °C (optimum, 25 °C) and at pH 6–9 (optimum, pH 7).
Cells grow optimally in the absence of NaCl but are able to tolerate 1 % NaCl.
Positive catalase reaction and weakly positive oxidase reaction.
No growth is observed under anaerobic conditions.
Nitrate is not reduced.
H2S and indole are not produced.
Arginine is not hydrolysed.
Positive for urease activity but negative for amylase, β-galactosidase and lipase activities and for aesculin hydrolysis.
Glucose and mannose are utilized as carbon and energy sources.
The following substrates are not utilized: arabinose, fructose, mannitol, maltose, gluconate, caprate, adipate, malate, citrate, pyruvate, xylose, starch, glycerol and cellobiose.

Susceptible to the following antibiotics (μg per disc): ampicillin (33), penicillin G (10), chloramphenicol (60), gentamicin (40), streptomycin (20), neomycin (20), kanamycin (30) and tetracycline (50); resistant to (μg per disc): bacitracin (60), vancomycin (70) and nalidixic acid (30).
The major cellular fatty acids are summed feature 3 (comprising iso-C15 : 0 2-OH and/or C16 : 1ω7c), C16 : 1ω5c, iso-C15 : 0 and C16 : 0; the complete fatty acid profile is given in Table 2.
The predominant menaquinone is MK-7.
The type strain, SPM-9T (=NCIMB 14407T=DSM 19989T), was isolated from a permafrost soil sample in the Adventdalen valley, Spitsbergen, northern Norway.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 49.1 mol%.
